data.worksheetTitle: Habit Improvement Practice - Square Root Signs & Exponential Rules
data.headerMessage: This is to help you gain more IB exam points by developing your habit / muscle memory to automatically do the right thing when writing answers. These targeted exercises are specially designed to break persistent mistakes and reinforce good habits.

targetHabits.description: Always include ± (plus-minus) notation when taking the square root of both sides of an equation
targetHabits.importance: Missing the negative root loses you marks in every IB exam question involving square roots. This is one of the most common mistakes that costs students 1-2 marks per question.

targetHabits.description: Always check if the denominator can equal zero before simplifying rational expressions
targetHabits.importance: Failing to identify division by zero issues shows lack of mathematical rigor and can lead to invalid solutions, losing marks in IB exams.

targetHabits.description: Remember that negative exponents indicate reciprocals: x⁻ⁿ = 1/xⁿ
targetHabits.importance: Mishandling negative exponents leads to completely wrong answers in exponential and logarithmic questions, a core IB HL topic.

exercises.question: Solve for x: x² = 49
hints: Remember that both positive and negative numbers square to give positive results
Use the ± symbol to show both solutions
exercises.commonMistake: Only writing x = 7 and forgetting the negative solution
exercises.keyReminder: Square roots ALWAYS have two solutions: one positive and one negative

exercises.question: Solve for x: (x - 3)² = 16
hints: Take the square root of both sides, remembering ±
Then solve two separate linear equations
exercises.commonMistake: Only finding x = 7 by forgetting the negative root
exercises.keyReminder: When you take a square root, you must include both the positive and negative values

exercises.question: Simplify: (2x + 6) / x
exercises.commonMistake: Simplifying without noting the restriction that x cannot equal zero
exercises.keyReminder: Always identify values that make the denominator zero - these are excluded from the domain

exercises.question: Simplify: x / (x² - 4)
hints: Identify which values of x make the denominator zero
exercises.correctAnswer: x / [(x-2)(x+2)], with restrictions x ≠ 2 and x ≠ -2
exercises.commonMistake: Not identifying that x cannot be 2 or -2
exercises.keyReminder: Factor denominators to find ALL values that would cause division by zero

exercises.question: Simplify: 2⁻³
hints: A negative exponent means 'take the reciprocal'
exercises.keyReminder: Negative exponents create fractions: move the base to the denominator and make the exponent positive

exercises.question: Simplify: (5x)⁻²
hints: Remember to square both the coefficient and the variable
exercises.commonMistake: Writing 1/(5x²) instead of 1/(25x²), forgetting to square the 5
exercises.keyReminder: When raising a product to a power, you must apply that power to each factor

exercises.question: Solve: x² - 2x - 15 = 0
hints: Factor or use the quadratic formula
Remember there should be two solutions
exercises.keyReminder: Quadratic equations typically have two solutions - make sure to find both

exercises.question: Express with positive exponents: 3x⁻¹y²
hints: Only the x has a negative exponent
Move only the x to the denominator
exercises.commonMistake: Moving everything to the denominator or handling the negative exponent incorrectly
exercises.keyReminder: Only terms with negative exponents move to the denominator; positive exponents stay in place

data.rationale: These exercises systematically address your three most common error patterns. By practicing these specific types of problems, you'll build automatic responses that prevent these mistakes. The key is repetition - your brain will learn to automatically include the ± symbol, check for division by zero, and correctly handle negative exponents. Each correct answer strengthens the neural pathway for the right habit. With consistent practice, these correct methods will become second nature, and you'll stop losing points on these common errors in your IB exams.
